awd_titl_txt: The Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (LSAMP) 2021 Principal Investigators/Project Directors Meeting
awd_abstract_narration:
The Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (LSAMP) program assists universities and colleges in diversifying the science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) workforce through their efforts at significantly increasing the numbers of students from historically underrepresented minority populations(African-Americans, Hispanic Americans, American Indians or Alaska Natives, NativeHawaiians or Other Pacific Islanders) to successfully complete high-quality degree programs in STEM. Chicago State University will lead an Organizing Committee to develop and hold a Principal Investigators/Project Directors (PI/PD) meeting. 

The conference will take place in a hybrid format over two days at the beginning of October, with both in-person attendance and virtual attendance at all the in-person sessions. The meeting will provide a forum for discussing the accomplishments of the program over the last 30 years, as well as the challenges and opportunities going forward, especially in light of COVID19 impacts. All LSAMP PIs and PDs will be invited to the meeting. As the last LSAMP PI/PD meeting was held in 2019, this meeting will provide the opportunity to foster and renew connections, to share information and resources gained in addressing pandemic-related issues, and plot a course going forward for the LSAMP community to meet the challenges of post-pandemic academia for groups underrepresented in STEM.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

NSF-HRD Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (LSAMP) Principal Investigators/Project Directors Meeting Project Outcomes.

Summary (Principal Investigators/ Project Directors Meeting):

The primary purpose of the 2021 LSAMP Principal Investigators and Project Directors Meeting was to bring together all LSAMP stakeholders (the NSF Program Officers/Directors, Business and Industry Partners, Principal Investigators, Project Directors and Associates) to meet, network and discuss progress, programming, and recent advances in broadening participation in STEM. This meeting, therefore, offered an opportunity for professional development and networking opportunities to all participants. The meeting, delivered as a hybrid (in-person and virtual), was held at the Hilton hotel, Rosemont/Chicago, on October 1st and 2nd, 2021. This meeting coincided with the 30th year of the Human Resource Development (HRD) division at the National Science Foundation (NSF) journey in broadening participation in STEM. Thus, the meeting was the beginning of a month long series of activities to commemorate the journey so far. The LSAMP PIs/PDs meeting on October 1st and 2nd, 2021, was bridged by two webinars, and culminated with the LSMRCE (Louis Stokes Midwest Regional Center of Excellence) annual conference on October 22nd through 24th.

Intellectual Merits: The overarching goal of the 2021 PIs/PDs Meeting was to provide an opportunity for the NSF LSAMP Program Officers/Directors and the Principal Investigators/Project Directors to assess the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic and the consequent impact on teaching and learning gains, especially on URM students within the STEM disciplines who would otherwise benefit from in-person hands-on research experiences. This in turn offered an opportunity to chart the way forward in a manner that addressed deficits that arose as a result of the 2020 highly consequential events. The event identified opportunities and challenges within the STEM ecosystem. Speakers included Dr. Diana Elder, the Director of the NSF Division of Human Resource Development. Other highly impactful sessions included Grant Award Management & Reporting, The Impact of COVID-19 on STEM Teaching and Learning, NSF LSAMP Listening Session, An Overview of the WebAMP Data Collection, Funding Opportunities etc.

Broader Impacts: The PIs/PDs meeting provided for a platform for all LSAMP stakeholders to foster networking and professionalism as it relates to broadening the participation of underrepresented minority in STEM. Among other professional development opportunities, Principal Investigators and Project Directors acquainted themselves with LSAMP best practices, grant award management, project evaluation, and WebAMP (online data reporting system) data input/management. Ultimately, the meeting empowered the PIs/PDs with evidence-based best practices that are essential to increasing URM students' retention, graduation, and career pathways in STEM. Ultimately, these efforts are aimed at increasing the number of URM students graduating with quality STEM degrees, and thus promoting the overarching goal of the NSF LSAMP - increasing the number and quality of URM students who graduate with STEM degrees and either join the STEM workforce or matriculate into graduate programs in STEM. Additionally, through these efforts, LSAMP for the very first time had a publication in the peer-reviewed journal, Frontiers in Education (an open access journal). This publication that has been compiled into an eBook (with hardcopy now available) has, as at today, reported 62,000 views and 7,000 downloads.
